title: Traditions of Edinburgh.
author: Chambers, Robert
snippet: About 1745, the London bag brought on one occasion no more than a single letter, addressed to the British Linen Company. From the Parliament Square the office was removed to Lord Covington's house, above described ; thence, after some years, to a house in North Bridge Street ; and thence, finally, to the present extensive buildings in Waterloo Place.

title: The novels and tales of Robert Louis Stevenson.
author: Stevenson, Robert Louis
snippet: I try to see him in bed; no go. I see him instead jumping up in his room in Waterloo Place (where exbypothesi he is not), sitting on the table, drawing out a very black briar-root pipe, and beginning to talk to a slim and ill- dressed visitor in a voice that is good to hear and with a smile that is pleasant to see. (After a little more than half an hour, the voice that was ill to hear has ceased, the cannonade is over.) And I am thinking how I can get an answering smile wafted over so many leagues of land and water, and can find no way.

title: London days;
author: Warren, Arthur
snippet: The majestic beauties of London seem to have developed by accident rather than by design. The view down Waterloo Place to the Abbey and the Victoria Tower and the view eastward from the Serpentine Bridge in Hyde Park have certainly done so. The view down the river from Waterloo Bridge, or Westminster, was never planned ; it grew slowly, being first blessed by every natural advantage that a patient Providence could bestow.

title: Here and there in the Home Land. England, Scotland and Ireland as seen by a Canadian. ... Profusely illustrated
author: Haight, Canniff.
snippet: Burns' Monument is onRegent Street, and to the right, Regent Terrace, a longrow of fine cut-stone residences, with tastefully arrangedgardens in front. The ascent to Waterloo Place is quitelong and steep. I take the road, which winds up the hill,past the Observatory7 on the one hand, and the monumentto Dugald Stewart on the other.

title: Here and there in the Home Land. England, Scotland and Ireland as seen by a Canadian. ... Profusely illustrated
author: Haight, Canniff.
snippet: I now descend to Waterloo Place, past the Post Office,to Princess Street, cross Waverley Bridge, and arrive atmy hotel—the Cockburn—about 4.30. That I was morethan a little weary may be taken for granted.

title: Literary landmarks of Edinburgh,
author: Hutton, Laurence
snippet: BURNS 39school, in a house on the southwest corner of St.James Square, in the New Town, and his was thetopmost, or attic, window in the gable looking towards the General Post-office, in Waterloo Place. Herefrom Burns wrote: "I am certain I saw you,Clarinda; but you don't look to the proper story fora poet's lodging — 'where speculation roosted nearthe sky.'

title: The Magicians of Edinburgh
author: Butlin, Ron
snippet: Designed in imitation of the Parthenon, it was begun in 1826 and abandoned unfinished when the money ran out. Sometimes, however, ghosts have other plans . . .The Completed Parthenon on Calton HillToiling along Princes Street, then up Waterloo Place, a Doric pillar on each shoulder. Victorious, immortal – us and our classically proportioned back-breaking loads.

title: The novels and tales of Robert Louis Stevenson.
author: Stevenson, Robert Louis
snippet: We shall be able to give you a decent welcome, and talk of old days. Apropos of old days, do you remember still the phrase we heard in Waterloo Place ? I believe you made a piece for the piano on that phrase. Pray, if you remember it, send it me in your next If you find it impossible to write correctly, send it me a la recitative, and indicate the accents.

title: The novels and tales of Robert Louis Stevenson.
author: Stevenson, Robert Louis
snippet: My dear sir, I grow more and more idiotic; I cannot even feign sanity. Sometime in the month of June a stalwart weather-beaten man, evidently of seafaring antecedents,  shall be observed wending his way between the Athenaeum Club and Waterloo Place. Arrived off No. 17.

title: Days of the past;
author: Shand, Alexander Innes
snippet: George Smith, then or soon after, had a mansion hard by, on Hampstead hill, with sloping lawns and gardens looking over to Harrow. His garden parties were gatherings of the select, where you came across the noted littdrateurs who were familiars of Waterloo Place, or thirled, as they say in Scotland, to the CornhilL There was a bedroom  in the Waterloo Place office, of which some of his familiars were free, when they cared to use it. title: Ten days abroad;
author: Fuller, Henry Starkey.
snippet: In the Calton Hill Cemetery there is a monument to the Highlanders who fell in the American Civil War, and one also to Abraham Lincoln. The Castle type of architecture  is reproduced in the prison pile on Waterloo Place, and reflected in the High School, although the latter has a Grecian portico, and in appearance is the most American-looking public school that I saw abroad. The University and its venerable walls I had merely a glance of, but I could not refrain from lingering a moment

title: Lucy, Francis and Cousin Bill. A novel, etc
author: Wistan, Aden.
snippet: She waited till the sound of the footsteps died inthe distance, and then ventured out. She lookedin eveiy direction, but saw no one she recognized,and then walked on along George Street to thePost Office in Waterloo Place.

title: A journal of a residence ... in London; including excursions through various parts of England; and a short tour in France and Scotland; in the years 1823 and 1824
author: Wheaton, Nathaniel Sheldon.
snippet: It is nearly sixty seet in height, and is perforated by one largearch, beneath which passes Calton Street, at the bottom ofthe ravine. The street built along Regent bridge is calledWaterloo Place ; and as some of the houses rise out of the

title: Great Britain, France and Belgium: a short tour in 1835
author: Humphrey, Heman
snippet: It is of a conical shape, and must originally have beenof difficult ascent, on all sides. A circuitous roadfrom Waterloo Place, now makes it accessible to carriages, as well as every class of pedestrians. Severalfine walks were formed around and near the summit,about twenty years ago, which at every step, presentviews of surpassing beauty and variety.

title: The novels and tales of Robert Louis Stevenson.
author: Stevenson, Robert Louis
snippet: Of what you say of the past, eh, man, it was a queer time, and awful miserable, but there 's no sense in denying it was awful fun. Do you mind the youth in Highland garb and the tableful of coppers ? Do you mind the SIGNAL of Waterloo Place ? Hey, how the blood stands to the heart at such a

title: Days of the past;
author: Shand, Alexander Innes
snippet: I remember the occasion well, for it was then I made the acquaintance of George Meredith. I happened to say to my host that I was only leaving one roof of his for another, and that, as I wanted exercise, I meant to walk to his bed in Waterloo Place. To my satisfaction, Meredith, who was also a great pedestrian and in the vio-our of his strengrth, declared he would accompany me.

title: Here and there in the Home Land. England, Scotland and Ireland as seen by a Canadian. ... Profusely illustrated
author: Haight, Canniff.
snippet: On our way through Waterloo Place to Princess Streetwe pass the new Post Office and Register Office. In frontof the latter is a fine equestrian statue of the Duke ofWellington.
